item.bib: Classen, E[rnest]. On Vowel Alliteration in the Old Germanic Languages. Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1913. 91 pp.
item.notes: Rev: by Klaeber in Anglia Beiblatt 25 (1914): 164–66; in JEGP 13 (1913): 449–51; in MLN 30 (1915): 108–14; in ANF 32 (1916): 125-28. Classen's monograph presents short summaries of the three theories so far pro- posed to explain the odd, seemingly anomalous rule of vowel alliteration in Old Germanic poetry (whereby any vowel may alliterate with any other, un- like the consonants, which may only echo identically); these are the Glottal Catch theory (proposed by Rapp [1836]), the Sonority theory (Jiriczek [1895], Kauffmann [1897], Saran [1907]), and the [Originally] Identical Vowel theory (Kock [1889–94], Jespersen [1904]). Classen himself supports the third of these--the theory that the vowels originally alliterated only individually but became confused in the normal course of sound-changes in the language--and provides analyses of Old English, Old Saxon, and Old Norse verse as evidence. As a point of information, Sievers, and Schipper after him, accepted the glottal-catch theory.

item.notes: Vol. 1: Part I: Einführendes, Grundbegriffe der Verslehre. Part II: Der altgermanische Vers. Vol. 2: Part III: Der altdeutsche Vers. Vol. 3: Part IV: Der frühneudeutsche Vers. Part V: Der neudeutsche Vers. Heusler is still the standard authority on German versification, despite later res- ervations by other workers about his metrical principles, which are Temporal- ist. English has no equivalent study either in range or in precision. The main relevance of Heusler to our own literature lies in the study of Old English versification: Heusler is one of the three or four major theorists, his work serving as the basis for Pope's later studies (J241, J242). See Pope's discussion on pp. 20–37 of J242. In Heusler's view each OE verse (half-line) consisted of two compound (four-member) measures, schematically | / x \ x | / x \ x ||, each member (x) representing the duration of one short syllable (= one quarter-note). Heusler uses musical notation freely but not structurally (that was Pope's addi- tion), but his arbitrary symbols translate into time-values thus: — half-note u eighth-note x quarter-note ^ quarter-pause. The signature then (not the tempo) is 4/4. Rests are employed freely everywhere except at the beginning of the line, since Heusler considers eve- rything before the first primary stress as anacrusis (i.e. extrametrical). It re- mained for Pope to add the initial rests and account for them.

item.notes: Proposes a scansion notation for stressed verse: the procedure is to count the number of weak syllables between (or before or after) each stress, denoting this information by a row of numbers. Thus, Longfellow's "Tell me not in mournful numbers / Life is but an empty dream," traditionally marked /x/x/x/x | /x/x/x/ would be marked 01111 | 01110, since only one weak syllable appears between each of the stresses in these traditionally "trochaic" lines.

item.notes: Summary of his lecture given at the convention. Luick adopts Sievers' theory of the "musical constants," the fixed tones, in verse, and gives here an expan- sion on the notion of Major and Minor modes in speech as in music. The Major is characteristically clear, light, distinct, having larger intervals, high pitch, and considerable rhetoric; the Minor is veiled, muffled, legato, having lower pitch and smaller intervals over syllables. Out of the moods in the words comes a melodic organization.

item.notes: Not conveniently accessible, but a valuable and very readable summary of what is known of the very earliest verseforms of the Germanic peoples, espe- cially ca. the 4th century. Marstrander's view is that alliteration originated in the Gaulish bardic schools, then spread to the Teutonic and Celtic tribes; in any event it can be found as far back as we can trace any other vestiges of Western European civilization outside the Empire. It is sobering to consider Caesar's Gallic Wars from the natives' point of view.

item.notes: R. P. Newton has managed to devise an analytic technique that, so far as I know, is entirely new in prosody. He is aware of Sievers' work on "speech- melody," he knows that duration is an aspect of melody equally as important as pitch, and he admits that the scansion of phonetic length (the old "quantities") has been fruitless; he proposes, though, that we mark patterns of phonemic length--i.e., the duration of the stressed vowels in a verse-line, making an as- sumption that the length of a vowel varies with the words it inhabits and fur- ther, the metrical context the words inhabit. Statistical analysis of some 3000 lines of German trochaic tetrameter (pp. 404–5) reveals some very interesting correlations of certain patterns with certain environments. Test case: a Bren- tano lyric.

item.notes: Repudiation of Hildebrand's view (L391) that alliteration is a subcategory of (identical with) Rime proper, and that the vowels following alliterating conso- nants must differ. Oertel emphasizes the different origins and effects of allitera- tion and rhyme (alliteration, depending on roots rather than suffixes, is much more difficult to achieve, for example), and shows that in 10–15% of all allit- eration the vowels will naturally coincide. In tone, though, this response is an over-reaction.

item.notes: The familiar sigh of despair over scansion terminology and method offers oc- casion for a lucid and much-illustrated synopsis of the modern system of ac- centual metrics, making an absolute distinction between the abstract metrical level and the concrete rhythmic level, marking both levels in the scansion of each line. Extensive examples of metrical variations. The one curiosity here (actually a serious inconsistency in theory) is that Rowley will allow both metrical rests (the full metrical paradigm is not filled out at every slot by an actual syllable) and also "slurring" [my phrase], "the elogation of two syllables [in the rhythm] to occupy the space of three" in the metrical paradigm. The first of these effects is problematic (Rowley allows rests to fill an entire foot; why not an entire line?), the second even more so, but worst of all, in practice we have no way to tell the two apart.

item.notes: The significance of the subject is evident: we have no scale for fixing degrees of rhymedness in poems. Ryder suggests several criteria, both phonological and non-phonological. Of the former, distribution patterns and frequencies of sounds in rhyme words compared to those in the whole language are especially useful; of the latter, repetition of morphemes or whole words, connotations, and patterns such as chiasmus are most important. Two German poems are analyzed.

item.bib: -----. "Off-Rhymes and Consonantal Confusion Groups: Some Hints from Mother Goose and the Volkslied." Lingua 12 (1963): 190-98.
item.notes: Acoustic researches by Miller and Nicely had shown that consonants may be sorted into a series of "confusion groups"--i.e., [p t k], [f th s sh], [b d g], [v dj z zh], and [m n]; a listener will mistake one consonant for another within each group but not between groups. Ryder ingeniously inquires whether or not the principle is preserved in off-rhymes (English and German folk verses), and it is. Implica- tion: "off-rhyme . . . is by no means a casual approximation of sounds. . . . rather, it has discriminated among sounds as to degree of similarity." Such ap- plications of acoustic facts as this deserve emulation.

item.notes: Chapter 1 surveys the versification of Skaldic poetry. Dróttkvætt was the most complex verseform evolved in all of the Germanic and Scandinavian lan- guages: strict rules stipulated internal rhyme, end rhyme, alliteration, and a po- etic diction for the eight-line, symmetrical stanza, each line of which had three stresses in six syllables and ended with an obligatory, penultimate, long stressed syllable followed by a final short unstressed syllable.

Snorri Sturluson [1179-1241]. Bók þessi heitir Edda. Hana hefir samansetta Snorri Sturlu sonr eptir peim hætti sem hér er skipat [Snorri's Edda, also known as the Prose Edda]. MSS ca. 1300.
item.notes: See now the critical ed. of Part III (the Poetic Edda) by Faulkes. Snorri's critical treatise/poem consists of three parts. The first provides an apo- logia for the beliefs of the Æsir and a survey of their mythology. The second discusses poetic diction--kennings and one other topic. The third is a 102- stanza, 100-meter praise poem intended as a display of virtuosity as well as a metrical catalogue, with prose commentaries between each stanza explaining the technique involved. "Edda" means poetics. The first known commentary on the Eddic poetry in Old Icelandic. For further discussion, see:

item.bib: Ciklamini, Marlene. Snorri Sturluson. Twayne's World Authors Series, no. 493. Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1978.
For bibliographic information on the Edda see Icelandica 13 (1920): 74–95; 37 (1955): 93–104.
